Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Massive Mobile Broadband Communications with Millimeter Wave Picocellular Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project considers cellular systems based in the millimeter wave (mmWave) bands, between 30 and 300 GHz, where the available bandwidths are much wider than today?s cellular networks [4-6]. Indeed, available spectrum at these frequencies can be easily 200 times greater than all cellular allocations today under 3 GHz. Moreover,the very small wavelengths of mmWave signals combined with advances in low-power CMOS RF
circuits enable large numbers of miniaturized antennas to be placed in small dimensions. These multiple antenna systems can be used to form very high gain, electrically steerable arrays, fabricated at the base station, in the skin of a cellphone, or even within a chip. Due to the limited range of mmWave signals, the proposal envisions cellular systems based on large numbers of mmWave ?picocells? (100 to 200m radius), each using highly directional antennas for improved range and spatial separation. Combining dramatically increased bandwidths with spatial multiplexing gains from the high-dimensional multiple antenna transmissions such mmWave picocellular systems offer the possibility of of 1000 times more capacity than current commercial networks.

This project will provide a basis for bringing mmWave technologies to a multiuser, multi-cellular setting and enable mmWave systems for wide-area networks with mobility. With partnerships from leading device vendors in this space, the PIs aim to drive the innovation forward in terms of device and protocol development, and train a new generation of students at the graduate and undergraduate level in this emerging area of wireless communications. The enhanced throughput gains that could approach 1000x current wireless cellular network throughputs would revolutionize the wireless broadband industry and lead to improved delivery of network services to users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The final year of this project helped support the completion of the Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering for two exceptional NYU WIRELESS students, Shu Sun and George MacCartney, and also supported the research endeavors of new Ph.D. students Yunchou Xing and Ojas Kanhere, and new MS student Shihao Ju.  Both Dr. Sun and Dr. MacCartney conducted pioneering research, using a vast database of real-world radio propagation measurements collected at 28 GHz and 73 GHz in New York City. Their work has led to fundamental understanding of millimeter-wave channels in urban environments, which has offered critical information to the global wireless industry as it seeks to build the world's first wireless standard that uses millimeter-wave frequencies -- 5G.

Both Dr. Sun and Dr. MacCartney were recipients of the prestegious Marconi Young Scholars award, and have published many highly cited papers that have helped lead the way for other reserachers in academia and industry. Their  accomplishments,  which were supported in part by this project, include:

1. New releases of an open-source channel modeing programl called NYUSIM, now downloaded more than 50,000 times.

2. Many journal papers and conference papers that describe the performance of Cooperative Multipoint (CoMP) coordination in millimeter wave (mmWave) cellular networks.

3. Many journal and conference papers that describe the small-scale channel fading characteristics of mmWave channels, including human blockage.

4. Many journal papers and conference papers that show the capacity limits and realistic implementation issues for Hybrid Beamforming at mmWave frequencies  in mobile environments.  These results are critical for future network provisioning as 5G is developed and deployed over the next decade. This body of work has also provided analytical expressiobns, the first ot their kind, for complex Hybrid Beamforming interference and capacity analysis.

5. Participation in the 5G Millimeter Wave Channel Alliance, a collaborative research effort involving many organizations and spearheaded by NIST.

To find the numerous publications and contributions based in part on this research project, one may simply do a websearch for the following terms:

"NYU WIRELESS NSF 1302336 "

Some of these works were performed in collaboration with Prof. Mansoor Shafi of Spark, New Zealand, whose participation is gratefully acknowledged.
